AboutSection.title: About the Event

section1.heading: II IWPPO 2025
section1.paragraph: The IWPPO was born from the need to discuss and find solutions for one of today's greatest environmental challenges: plastic pollution in the oceans. Originating from CEMEIA and supported by CAPES (PAEP), our workshop brings together international experts in an interdisciplinary approach.

section2.heading: Our Approach
section2.paragraph: The workshop combines scientific research, public policies, and technological innovation to address the issue of plastic pollution. With participants from various countries, we promote the exchange of knowledge and practical solutions.

highlights: Endorsed by the UN Executive Committee
Aligned with SDG 14 - Life Below Water

RegistrationSection.title: Registration
RegistrationSection.description: Choose the plan that best suits your needs and secure your participation in the II International Workshop on Public Policy Research and Social Development.
RegistrationSection.subtitle: Secure Your Spot
RegistrationSection.additional_info_1: Students must present valid proof of enrollment.
RegistrationSection.additional_info_2: Payment can be made via PIX, credit card, or bank slip.
RegistrationSection.additional_info_3: In case of cancellation, a 70% refund is available up to 30 days before the event.
RegistrationSection.additional_info_4: Proof of registration category is required at the time of registration.
RegistrationSection.evaluation_1: The first step consists of a preliminary evaluation by the steering committee, which examines whether the work aligns with the event's scope and meets formatting and submission requirements.
RegistrationSection.evaluation_2: The second step involves an evaluation by the Scientific Committee of the Workshop on Plastic Pollution in the Oceans. Papers will be reviewed by two evaluators based on the following criteria:
RegistrationSection.evaluation_3: Originality - Classification relative to the state of the art - Contribution - Methodological Rigor - Writing Quality. Each criterion may receive one of the following ratings, which will be converted into numerical values:
RegistrationSection.evaluation_4: Very Poor = 01 - Poor = 02 - Fair = 03 - Good = 04 - Very Good = 05. Authors MAY BE NOTIFIED WITH: - ACCEPTED (average score of 4 or higher) - REJECTED (average score below 4)
RegistrationSection.evaluation_7: Oral presentation: 10 minutes for presentation + 5 minutes for questions

EixosTematicos.descricao: Choose one of the axes below to submit your scientific paper
EixosTematicos.envie_trabalho: Submit your paper now on Doity

itens.descricao: This thematic axis addresses the current state of the oceans in the face of contemporary environmental challenges. It aims to gather studies that assess the health of marine ecosystems, highlighting indicators of environmental degradation, biodiversity loss, acidification, overfishing, and climate change impacts. Research using monitoring tools, ocean modeling, and conservation policy evaluation is also welcome. The goal is to provide a comprehensive and scientific overview of the oceans' actual condition on local, regional, and global scales.

This axis covers research focused on the identification, characterization, and mitigation of pollutants in marine environments, with a special emphasis on emerging contaminants such as microplastics, nanoplastics, pharmaceutical residues, pesticides, and heavy metals. Papers investigating sources, dispersion routes, ecotoxicological effects, and possible solutions for these contaminants are expected. Innovative approaches in detection technologies, remediation, and prevention strategies with a focus on marine sustainability are also included.

itens.titulo: Science with Purpose: Applied Ocean Research
itens.descricao: This axis highlights applied science as a strategic tool to address ocean challenges. Research involving remote sensing monitoring, climate modeling, marine biotechnology, and solutions based on emerging technologies such as Artificial Intelligence and Big Data is welcome. The focus is on producing technical knowledge with a direct impact on conservation, management, and sustainable use of the seas.

This axis addresses the importance of traditional knowledge and the role of coastal communities in ocean preservation. It values interdisciplinary studies on sustainable practices, environmental justice, and the impacts of the climate crisis on the lives of indigenous peoples, artisanal fishers, shellfish gatherers, and riverine communities. It encourages dialogue between science and local knowledge as a strategy for fairer and more effective policies.

This axis focuses on the dissemination of scientific knowledge and the strengthening of ocean literacy. It includes initiatives for science popularization, production of educational materials, actions in schools and communities, and communication strategies aimed at social mobilization and support for public policies. Papers exploring risk communication in the context of climate crises are also expected.

This axis explores the role of public policies in the protection and sustainable management of oceans. It covers topics such as multilateral agreements, the creation of marine protected areas, national legal instruments, participatory governance, and transparency in coastal management. This axis seeks to articulate science, society, and the state to promote effective and equitable ocean governance.

This axis promotes innovative approaches to the regeneration and preservation of marine environments. It includes research on coastal ecosystem restoration, ocean renewable energies, blue economy, sustainable production chains, and nature-based technologies. The goal is to stimulate solutions that reconcile socioeconomic development with ecological integrity.

itens.titulo: Oceans and Climate: Interactions and Impacts
itens.descricao: This axis analyzes the role of oceans in the global climate system and the effects of climate change on marine and coastal environments. Studies on extreme events, sea-level rise, acidification, impacts on vulnerable communities, and mitigation and adaptation strategies are welcome. The emphasis is on understanding and responding to climate risks with a solid scientific foundation.
